Fig. 1 Historic crude oil (Western Texas Intermediate) price [9] (prices corrected for inflation using headline CPI) and commissioning of XTL-processes (length of line proportional to design capacity). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Measured CO-conversion (left) and yield of Fischer-Tropsch products (right) as a function of space velocity (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Difference between the productivity (Pr) over cobalt-based catalyst at 220°C and 20bar and over an alumina containing iron-based catalyst at 250°C and 20bar as a function of the conversion of CO + CO2 (activity factor or cobalt-based catalyst has been increased by aCo; SCO2 for cobalt-based catalysts 0%; SCO2 for iron-based catalysts: 30%). Top: Feed H2/CO/inert=2/1/0; Bottom: H2/CO/inert=2/1/3 Left: Plug flow conditions; Right: Mixed flow conditions Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Thermodynamic analysis of the oxidation of metallic cobalt (left) and Hägg iron carbide (right) to Co(II)O and Fe3O4 respectively as a function of the average particle size for a feed of H2/CO/inert=2/1/0 and H2/CO/inert=2/1/3, respectively (two extreme cases have been considered for the oxidation of Hägg iron carbide, viz. no CO2 formation and water gas shift at equilibrium). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Selectivity for CO2 as a function of the CO-conversion of CO (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1; dotted line is the equilibrium CO2-selectivity for a feed with H2/CO2 at 250°C). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2/CO-ratio at the reactor exit (left) and the H2/CO-usage ratio (right) as a function of CO-conversion for a feed with H2/CO2 (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Methane content (top), C2 C4 selectivity (middle) and C5+-selectivity (bottom), all on a CO2-free basis, as a function of CO-conversion for a feed with H2/CO2 (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Chain growth probability in the range C8 C11 as a function of CO-conversion for a feed with H2/CO2 (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Olefin content in the fraction of linear hydrocarbons (left: C3; right: n-C5) as a function of CO-conversion for a feed with H2/CO2 (25wt.-% Co/TiO2 reduced in H2 at 350°C for 16h and tested at T=220°C; p=25bar; H2/CO/inert=2/1/3; iron-based catalysts activated in synthesis gas at 270°C for 16h and tested at T=250°C, p=21bar, H2/CO/inert=2/1/1). Research paper Comparing a cobalt-based catalyst with iron-based catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch XTL-process operating at high conversion E. van Steen ⁎ M. Claeys K.P. Möller D. Nabaho Centre for Catalysis Research, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Private Bag X3, Rondebosch, 7701, South Africa Centre for Catalysis Research Department of Chemical Engineering University of Cape Town Private Bag X3 Rondebosch 7701 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The XTL-process is a capital-intensive process. Novel process configurations need to be explored to increase the economic viability of this process. This is typically performed using the known dependencies of the catalyst as a function of the targeted process conditions. However, new process conditions may require catalysts with different characteristics compared to those currently utilised. Here, a set of cobalt- and iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts are evaluated for their suitability in the application of a single-pass XTL-process operating at high conversion of synthesis gas. It is shown that cobalt-based catalysts of a suitable activity may be preferred over iron-based catalysts. The higher selectivity for methane for cobalt-based catalysts is offset by a lower selectivity for C2-C4 resulting in a favourable C5+-selectivity. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch Cobalt Iron Activity Selectivity 1 Introduction The XTL process is the production of liquid fuels from a variety of carbon-containing feedstock via synthesis gas. It is a versatile process, since it can be adapted to a variety of feedstock. Synthesis gas can be obtained from gaseous carbon-containing materials (e.g. natural gas, biogas, biomass and even waste) using partial oxidation [1], steam reforming [2] or auto-thermal reforming [3]. Biomass can be converted into synthesis gas in a single step process [4,5], although a two-phase process seems to be preferred (i.e. torrefaction or mild pyrolysis followed by gasification) [6]. Char formed in this process can be can be converted into synthesis gas in the same manner as coal or heavy oil by gasification in the presence of oxygen and water [7,8]. Different feedstock will yield synthesis gas with different H2/CO-ratios, which may need to be adjusted using the water-gas shift reaction after clean-up of the synthesis gas. Liquid products are targeted as a fuel because of their high energy content per unit volume, which make them attractive to power long-haul transport. Hence, the XTL-process can be seen as an attractive route for introduction of fuels from a renewable feedstock into existing, well-established market for liquid fuels. However, this process competes with the existing well-established crude-oil based route and the pricing of the targeted products, liquid fuels, is thus inherently coupled to the price of crude oil with its strong fluctuations (see Fig. 1 ). For instance, the price of crude oil declined strongly 3 years ago dipping even to prices previously encountered in the period 1985–2005. The strong fluctuations in the oil price poses a high economic and financial risk for the introduction of technologies making use of alternative feedstock whose price is not coupled to that of crude oil. The product price, which is linked to the strongly fluctuating oil price, must offset the high capital investment for this type of processes (see Table 1 ). The high capital cost for XTL-installations has long been recognized as an impediment in the installation of new plants. Jaramillo et al. [10] estimated in 2008 a total capital cost of 22 500–34 000 US$ per bbl/day production capacity for GTL and 79 000–101 000 US$ per bbl/day production capacity for CTL (prices corrected for inflation using headline CPI). It should be noted that the actual relative capital cost per unit design capacity for the last two units coming on stream is much higher than typically quoted in literature which may be attributed to the much higher engineering, procurement and construction (EPC)-costs [11] and, in the case of the Escravos GTL-project, the long delays in construction [12]). Based on the typical investment costs, it is thought that the Fischer-Tropsch XTL-process can be competitive at a crude oil price of $44 per barrel when using natural gas as the feedstock, $74 per barrel when using coal as a feedstock and $92 per barrel when using biomass as a feedstock [13–15]. It should however be realized that this is strongly dependent on the locality of production, the cost for the feedstock and imposed carbon taxes. Nevertheless, the high capital cost poses a risk to the implementation of the Fischer-Tropsch process and reduction of capital and operating cost in the overall flowsheet should be of paramount interest. The time, at which a new technology is brought on line in relation to the price of crude oil, will become a determining, albeit an unpredictable factor in the economic viability of the process. A major part of the cost of any XTL-process lies in the production of synthesis gas. In the Fischer-Tropsch process, and depending on the feedstock between 45% and 70% of the total capital cost investment is associated with synthesis gas generation [8]; the lower end of the scale is associated with gas-to-liquid (GTL) processes and the higher end of the scale is associated with gasification of solid feedstock such as coal or biomass after torrefaction. Here, air separation may amount for ca. 30% of the cost for synthesis gas generation. The high cost of synthesis gas generation has long been recognized as a hurdle for low-cost conversion of feedstock into liquid fuels using the Fischer-Tropsch technology [19,20], and hence air-blown gasifiers have been proposed to reduce the costs. It has been argued [20–22] that XTL-processes utilizing air-blown gasifiers are energetically more expensive than processes utilizing oxygen blown gasifiers. However, utilizing synthesis gas in a once-through operation in conjunction with an efficient use of the off-gas may still offer an opportunity to reduce the overall cost of the process. Current XTL-processes operate at a relative low conversion per pass and thus necessitating the use of a recycle to obtain high overall synthesis gas conversion. Gasification with air results in a nitrogen-rich synthesis gas. Hedden et al. [19,22–28] reported on the use of nitrogen-rich synthesis gas for the Fischer-Tropsch process focussing on the use of an iron-based catalyst in a tubular reactor. Their analysis showed that a CO-conversion of 55% can be achieved with a nitrogen-rich synthesis gas (H2/CO∼2) without runaways using two consecutive tubular reactors with intermediate wax/diesel/water removal [27]. Syntroleum (nowadays the Renewable Energy Group) has patented a similar process [29,30] using a cobalt-based catalyst employed in a two-stage process with intermediate product and water removal. The unconverted synthesis gas in these processes can be used for power generation [15,23,29]. The design of a single-pass synthesis gas conversion requires detailed knowledge on the dependency of the activity/selectivity of the Fischer-Tropsch process on the conversion, and in particular at high conversion. Unfortunately, not many studies on the dependency of activity/selectivity on the conversion have been published and in particular not with a focus on operation at high levels of conversion. Recently, the group of Davis/Bukur reported on the dependency of the selectivity of the Fischer-Tropsch process on a Ru-Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in a slurry reactor [31] and on a Co/γ-Al2O3-catalyst in a fixed bed reactor [32], which can be used to assess the viability of operating at a high single pass conversion. The observed selectivity effects were mainly discussed in terms of increased water partial pressure of water in the reactor and in particular re-oxidation of the catalyst caused by water [31,33]. Here we report on a study comparing the performance of a cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst with iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts when targeting a high conversion, in particular when dealing with a feed containing inerts (as e.g. obtained when gasifying/reforming with air instead of oxygen). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Four different catalysts were prepared, viz. an impregnated Co/TiO2 catalyst, and precipitated Fe-based catalysts (100 Fe: 5Cu: 5K2O: 25 SiO2, 100 Fe: 6K2O: 30 Al2O3, and a ruthenium promoted iron-based catalyst 100 Fe/4 Ru/6K2O/30 Al2O3). The impregnated cobalt catalyst was prepared by slurry impregnation of the titania support, P25 (Degussa), with an aqueous 1.35M Co(NO3)2 solution in a single impregnation step to yield a cobalt loading in the reduced catalyst of 23wt.-%. The catalyst precursor was dried under reduced pressure at 85°C for 1h and subsequently calcined in a fluidized bed in air at 400°C for 3h. The preparation of the iron-based catalyst with a composition on a weight basis of 100 Fe/5 Cu/5K2O/25 SiO2 was prepared using a precipitation method based on the preparation method for the Ruhrchemie catalyst [34,35]. An iron and copper nitrate solution at 60°C (2g/l Cu and 40g/l Fe respectively) was added step-wise to an agitated sodium carbonate solution at 60°C (100g/l Na2CO3) until a slurry with a pH of 7 was obtained. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with warm (60°C) deionised water to remove excess sodium from the precipitate. The washed precipitate was re-slurried in deionised water. The resulting slurry was subsequently filtered and the filtrate washed with warm deionised water (60°C). The washed filtrate was re-slurried with deionised water, to which a potassium silicate solution was added to obtain the desired Si and K loadings. After precipitation of the silica at pH 7 (by addition of a nitric acid solution), the resultant slurry was again filtered and the filtrate added to deionised water to obtain a slurry with 20wt.-% solids. The slurry was spray-dried, after which the dried catalyst was calcined in air at 400°C. The resulting particle size was 83±67μm. The preparation of the alumina containing iron-based catalyst with a composition on a weight basis of 100 Fe/6K2O/30 Al2O3 was carried out via co-precipitation of an aqueous iron nitrate and aluminium nitrate solution at its boiling point using ammonium carbonate as the precipitation agent. The catalyst precursor was filtered off and the filter cake dried in an oven at 100°C for 24h and subsequently calcined at 350°C for 16h. Potassium was added by impregnation of the catalyst precursor (d=240–300μm) with the appropriate amount of an aqueous KNO3 solution. Some of the calcined catalyst precursor was impregnated with a solution containing Ru3(CO)12 in n-hexane to obtain a catalyst with the composition 100 Fe/4 Ru/6K2O/30 Al2O3. 2.2 Fischer-Tropsch testing The Fischer-Tropsch activity and selectivity were investigated in a slurry reactor. The 1L autoclave was filled with 280g of wax, which was then melted at 120°C, after which the catalyst was added. The impregnated cobalt-based catalyst first underwent an ex-situ reduction (vide supra) in a hydrogen flow of 5 ml(NTP)/min/g of H2 at 350°C for 16h with a ramp of 5°C/min. The wax-coated, reduced catalyst (22g) was added to the reactor under argon sparging, after which the reactor was pressurized to 25bar and heated to reaction temperature (220°C). The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was performed using a synthesis gas with H2/CO/Ar=2/1/3 (mimicking a synthesis gas obtained by gasification/reforming using air). The iron-based catalysts (m=5g) were activated in-situ in synthesis gas (H2/CO=2) at 1bar and 270°C for 16h, after which the reactor was cooled down to the reaction temperature (250°C) and pressurized to 21bar. The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was performed using a synthesis gas with H2/CO/Ar=2/1/1. The flow rate of each gas was controlled independently by a mass flow controller, after which the gases were mixed. The synthesis gas mixture was fed into the slurry reactor. The reactor product passed a hot trap maintained at 220°C and a cold trap, which was maintained at room temperature to remove water and alcohols before being sent to vent. A sample of the permanent gases was taken after the cold trap, which was analysed on a 3-channel micro gas chromatograph Varian CP-4900 equipped with a TCD. Conversion, yield and selectivity were determined by using the inert component in the feed gas as an internal standard. A sample of the organic product was taken after the hot trap gas using the off-line ampoule sampling technique [36], which were analysed on a Varian CP-3P-3800 equipped with a FID. The yield of organic product compounds was determined using methane as the link component. 3 Results and discussion Fischer-Tropsch tests were carried out in a well-mixed slurry reactor to ensure that all particles are exposed to the same reaction conditions and statements on the effect of changing conversion level on the activity and selectivity can be made. The level of CO-conversion obtained over the various catalysts was systematically varied by changing the space velocity keeping temperature, pressure and feed gas composition constant (see Fig. 2 ). The obtained activity of the 25wt.-% Co/TiO2 was low, but was comparable to that reported for other unpromoted Co/TiO2-catalysts [37,38]. It was further noted that this catalyst deactivated, since repeat measurements at the same space velocity of 30mln/(g.min) resulted in a steady decrease in the measured CO-conversion (see also Supplementary Material). The maximum yield of Fischer-Tropsch products obtained over the unpromoted Co/TiO2-catalyst reached ca. 92% and was essentially equal to the CO-conversion due to the lack of significant formation of CO2 under these conditions (a maximum of selectivity for CO2 of 2.3C-% was determined at high CO-conversion). The activity of the catalyst 100 Fe/5Cu/5K2O/25 SiO2 catalyst was in line with the activity of the well-documented Ruhrchemie catalyst activated in a similar manner (see e.g. [39]). The CO-conversion increased with decreasing space velocity. The iron-based catalyst produced significant amounts of CO2 (with CO2-selectivity between 15 and 30C-%). CO2 production is typically attributed to the water gas shift activity of these catalysts, but has also been postulated to originate from in-situ carburization of magnetite [40,41]. The formation of CO2 limits the yield of Fischer-Tropsch products to a maximum ca. 70C-% over this catalyst. The activity of the alumina containing iron-based catalysts as expressed as the CO-conversion and the yield of Fischer-Tropsch products was lower at high space velocity and higher at low space velocity than the Ruhrchemie-based iron catalyst (100 Fe/5 Cu/5K2O/25 SiO2). The highest yield of Fischer-Tropsch products over iron-based catalysts of 75C-% was obtained over 100 Fe/6K2O/30 Al2O3. This can be ascribed to the higher activity of this catalyst at high levels of CO-conversion seeing that the CO2-selectivity with this catalyst was comparable to that of the Ruhrchemie-based iron catalyst (vide verde). The addition of ruthenium to the iron-alumina catalyst did not change the CO-conversion at a given space velocity, but increased CO2-formation resulting in a reduced yield of Fischer-Tropsch products. The yield of Fischer-Tropsch products as a function of conversion was fitted to a set of kinetic expressions (realizing that there are many published kinetic expressions [42–46]) to gain insight in the dependency of the rate on the CO-conversion. It should be noted that discrimination between kinetic models was not attempted due to the strong correlation between the kinetic variables in this limited analysis. Inhibition of the rate of formation of Fischer-Tropsch products seems to be important for cobalt-based catalysts, but not for iron-based catalysts (see Table 2 ). It is further interesting to note that the activity factor for the alumina-containing iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts is significantly higher than that for the Ruhrchemie-based catalyst; the addition of Ru to the catalyst formulation does not seem to affect the activity factor nor the inhibition factor much. The obtained kinetic expressions can be used to explore the productivity obtained over cobalt-based catalysts relative to the productivity over iron-based catalysts. The productivity is the integral amount mass of organic product compounds formed in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and thus proportional to the amount of Fischer-Tropsch products formed (inmolC) per unit time and per unit mass of catalyst. The measured activity of the used Co/TiO2 catalyst in this study was low and hence the activity of the catalyst was increased with a factor aCo to see when a cobalt-based catalyst operating at 220°C yields a higher productivity than the alumina-containing iron-based catalyst at 250°C (the activity of the cobalt-based catalyst can be increased by promoting with noble metals [47,48] or with metal oxides [49,50]). Cobalt-based catalysts with an activity at least 3-3.5 time higher than the catalyst used in this study become competitive with the tested iron-based catalyst. It can be noted that the cobalt-based catalyst can be more active than iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst at high conversion, but not necessarily at low conversion as previously noted by van Berge and Everson [51]. This has previously been ascribed [51] to the inhibition of the rate of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over iron-based catalysts by water and the lack of the inhibition term present in rate expressions used to describe the behaviour over cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [43,46]. In the analysis presented here, water partial pressure does not affect the rate of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over either type of catalysts, and the observed preference of cobalt-based catalysts over iron-based catalysts at high conversion might be ascribed to the stronger dependency of the rate of reaction on the partial pressure of reactants over the iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst (in particular due to the relative small value for the inhibition factor). A higher activity of cobalt-based catalysts in comparison to iron-based catalysts can be more easily observed in mixed flow reactors than in plug flow reactors since the productivity in the latter is the result of exposure to an on average higher partial pressures of reactant. Furthermore, operating at a lower pressure or using a diluted feed at the same total pressure thus resulting in a lower partial pressure of the reactants, will favour cobalt-based catalysts more than iron-based systems. The kinetic analysis above is devoid of any consideration on the effect of operational catalyst deactivation [40] due to oxidation. The catalytically active phase (metallic cobalt in cobalt-based catalysts [52,53], and iron carbide in iron-based catalysts [54,55]) may oxidise under Fischer-Tropsch conditions resulting in a loss in activity. Oxygen is introduced on the catalyst surface via CO-cleavage. Its removal yielding water is not a facile reaction step [56,57]. Oxygen may in a parallel reaction pathway diffuse into the lattice thus yielding the oxide phase. The formation of the oxide phase may be a reversible loss in activity when operating at high levels of conversion, if the re-reduction/re-carburization of the thus formed oxide phase is facile and further reaction the oxide phase (e.g. with the support) can be prevented [58]. The propensity of the catalytic active phase to transform into the oxide phase can be evaluated as a function of the crystallite size of the catalytically active phase by considering the thermodynamic limits of the oxidation of a single crystallite of the catalytically active phase yielding a single crystallites of the oxide phase. The overall process of oxidation yielding multiple smaller crystallites of the oxide phase by cleaving off of the oxide phase due to density differences, will be thermodynamically less favoured, due to the increase in the surface energy contribution of the oxide phase. although kinetic factors may favour this route. This analysis does not consider the possible interaction with other components present in the catalyst system such as support/binders ad promoters, which may affect the overall process as well. Cobalt crystallites of a size larger than 8nm will not oxidize as long as the CO-conversion remains below 96% (see Fig. 4 ). The presence of inert material in the feed would thermodynamically not affect the propensity of metallic cobalt to oxidise under Fischer-Tropsch conditions. The thermodynamic driving force for the oxidation of metallic cobalt to Co(II)O will be reduced if the oxidation process results in cleaving off multiple, smaller cobalt oxide crystallites since this would increase the surface energy contribution. The transformation of Hägg iron carbide into magnetite is thermodynamically affected by the ratio p H 2 O 26 / ( p H 2 26 · p C O 6 ) . The presence of inert in the feed will lower the partial pressure of both the reactants and the products, and as a net effect lower this ratio resulting in a lower conversion at which phase transition of Hägg iron carbide into magnetite takes place. Hägg carbide crystals are of course more stable, if the partial pressure of water is decreased e.g. by the water gas shift reaction. The oxidation of iron carbide may result in the cleavage off of multiple, smaller magnetite crystallites due to the difference in the density. It has been observed that iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts often contain larger magnetite crystals and smaller iron carbide crystals (in conjunction with small, superparamagnetic iron oxide) [40,41], and it may be postulated that small magnetite crystallites sinter under Fischer-Tropsch conditions. The commercial application of the Fischer-Tropsch process for the XTL-process is not only dictated by the activity of the catalyst, but also by the obtained selectivity towards the desired products (generally summed together as C5+) and the undesired product compounds, CO2, CH4 and C2-C4. The obtained CO2-selectivity obtained over cobalt-based catalysts is low (see Fig. 5 ). As previously reported [31,32], an increase in the CO2-selectivity with increasing CO-conversion was obtained reaching ca. 3C-% at a CO-conversion 91%. This was tentatively attributed to formation of the oxide phase [31], although it may also be related to a decrease in the partial pressures of the reactants (and in particular hydrogen) resulting in a switch in the rate controlling step of the removal of surface oxygen [59,60]. A much higher CO2-selectivity was obtained over iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts, although the water gas shift reaction is at the tested conditions not at equilibrium. The Ruhrchemie-type catalyst, 100 Fe/5 Cu/5K2O/25 SiO2, shows the commonly observed increase in CO2-selectivity with increasing CO-conversion [61]. The CO2-selectivity obtained over the alumina containing iron-based catalyst, 100 Fe/6K2O/30 Al2O3, at high levels of CO-conversion is similar to the one obtained over Ruhrchemie-based catalyst, but the CO2 selectivity is almost independent of the CO-conversion. Interestingly, promoting the alumina containing iron-based catalyst with Ru resulted in a strong increase in the CO2-selectivity. The formation of significant amounts of CO2 over iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts is a draw-back when dealing with a synthesis gas with H2/CO2, since it reduces the amount of liquid products which can be formed. Co-production of CO2 in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis implies that the usage ratio of hydrogen to carbon monoxide will deviate significantly from the H2/CO ratio in the feed. Therefore, the H2/CO-ratio, to which the catalyst is being exposed, differs (sometimes widely) from the inlet H2/CO-ratio. The usage ratio for the cobalt-based catalyst is ca. 2.18 (see Fig. 6 ), which is similar to the one reported previously before [62]: cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis with a H2/CO-ratio at the reactor inlet of 2 will thus have a H2/CO-ratio at the exit of the reactor of less than 2, and the reaction mixture will be enriched in carbon monoxide. Co-production of CO2 during the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis results in H2/CO-usage ratio much less than the feed ratio of 2. Hence, the exit stream will be enriched in hydrogen [39], and (H2/CO)-ratios in the exit gas over iron-based catalysts was as high as 5–10 when the CO-conversion increased to 80%. The desired product in the XTL-process are liquid hydrocarbons, typically summarized as C5+; methane together with the C2-C4 product compounds represent a loss in the liquid yield of the process and are therefore undesired. A high selectivity for the desired C5+-fraction of ca. 90C-% is obtained with Co/TiO2 in the range of CO-conversion between 30 and 70%. It drops to ca. 83C-%, when the CO-conversion is increased to 91%. The methane selectivity is relatively constant at ca. 6C-% for CO-conversions between 30 and 60% (see Fig. 7 ). However, a significantly higher methane selectivity of ca. 10C-% was observed when increasing the CO-conversion to ca. 90%. This might be explained by a lifting of the inhibition of the surface reactions by CO resulting in a higher extent of hydrogenation of surface species [63,64], and thus an increase in the selectivity towards methane. The strong increase in methane selectivity at high levels of CO-conversion over cobalt-based catalysts might then be prevented by promoting cobalt-based catalysts with elements such as Mn [49], which increase the adsorption constant for CO relative to the one for hydrogen, and/or operating at higher pressures. The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over the Ruhrchemie-type catalyst, 100 Fe/5 Cu/5K2O/25 SiO2, show a very similar dependency of the C5+-selectivity on the CO-conversion dropping 90–94 C-% for conversion levels less than 75% going down to 77C-% at XCO =92%. The methane selectivity obtained with the iron-based catalyst (<3C-% if the CO-conversion is less than 75%) is much lower than the methane selectivity obtained with Co/TiO2 (ca. 6–7 C-% if the CO conversion is less than 70%). The low methane selectivity over this iron-based catalyst is offset by a higher selectivity for C2 C4 compounds over this catalyst resulting in almost identical C5+-selectivity over this iron-based catalyst in comparison to the C5+-selectivity obtained over Co/TiO2. The strong increase in methane selectivity (on a CO2-free basis) and the decrease in the C5+-selectivity at high conversion is accompanied by an increase in the selectivity for C2-C4 product compounds resulting in a strong decrease of the C5+-selectivity with increasing CO-conversion. This may be attributed to the strong decrease in the partial pressures of the reactants in conjunction with a strong increase in the H2/CO ratio resulting a more hydrogenating environment for the catalyst. The methane selectivity (on a CO2-free basis) obtained over the alumina-containing iron-based catalyst, 100 Fe/6K2O/30 Al2O3, at a CO-conversion level of ca. 85% is similar to that obtained with the cobalt-based catalyst (ca. 5–6 C-%). The high selectivity towards C2-C4 product compounds results in a rather low selectivity for C5+-products. With increasing level of CO-conversion, the selectivity towards light products, methane and C2-C4, increases less strongly compared to the trend obtained with the Ruhrchemie-type iron-based catalyst. Hence, the C5+-selectivity over this catalyst decreases with increasing conversion not as strongly as observed over the Ruhrchemie-based catalyst. The selectivity of this catalyst may be further improved by increasing the level of potassium in the catalyst, although this may come at the cost of reduced activity [65,66]. The addition of ruthenium to the alumina containing iron-based catalyst has a surprisingly negative effect on the methane selectivity; it is already larger than 10C-% (on a CO2-free basis) at a CO-conversion of ca. 40–50% and increases rapidly with increasing CO-conversion reaching ca. 25C-% at a conversion of ca. 90%. The high methane selectivity may originate from the catalytic activity of metallic ruthenium, since the applied reaction temperature is rather high for this catalytically active metal for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [67]. This, aided by the high H2/CO-ratio, may have lifted the inhibition for desorption of species on the ruthenium surface thus resulting in a high methane selectivity. The C5+-selectivity only indicates the potential for liquid product formation in the overall process, rather than the actual liquid product formation. The liquid product recovered from the Fischer-Tropsch product needs to be hydrocracked to obtain the correct carbon number distribution in the liquid product to satisfy the requirement for its use as a transportation fuel. The feed into the hydrocracker determines the required severity of cracking and thus the amount of gas produced in this unit. A reactor model including the essential aspects of the hydrocracker [68] is thus required to predict the effect of the carbon number distribution of the feed to the hydro-cracker on the obtained selectivity in the desired carbon number range. The carbon number distribution in the liquid fraction of the product is typically indicated by the chain growth probability. Although the ideal Anderson-Schulz-Flory distribution assumes a constant chain growth probability, this is not observed experimentally [64], and the chain growth probability may increase with increasing carbon number due to olefin readsorption [69]. Hence, the chain growth probability tends to a constant value, when the olefin content as a function of carbon number tends to zero. The chain growth probability in the carbon number range C8-C11 is typically higher in the CO-hydrogenation over Co/TiO2 in comparison to the iron-based catalysts (see Fig. 8 ). The chain growth probability decreases with increasing CO-conversion over these catalysts. With increasing conversion, the partial pressure of CO will decrease thereby lifting the inhibition of the product desorption in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis by CO [64]. Hence, a decrease in the chain growth probability can be expected. This may be countered by designing catalysts which chemisorb CO more strongly that the current set of catalysts. The chain growth probability in the carbon number range C8-C11 over the alumina-containing iron-based catalysts show a much larger variability, but the data seem to suggest that the chain growth probability is only a weak function of the level of CO-conversion. A comparison of different catalysts for the once-through Fischer-Tropsch operation requires a detailed understanding of the product composition leaving the Fischer-Tropsch reactor (see Supplementary Material), and not only the carbon number distribution. The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis produces both olefins and paraffins. Olefins may undergo secondary reactions, such as hydrogenation and incorporation into growing chains. Fig. 9 shows the olefin content in two carbon number fractions as a function of CO-conversion. The olefin content decreases with increasing CO-conversion, and the decrease is stronger over the supported cobalt-based catalyst in comparison to the iron-based catalyst, in line with previously shown dependencies of the olefin content on in particular the partial pressure of carbon monoxide over iron- and cobalt-based catalysts [64]. It should however be noted that the primary olefin content over cobalt-based catalysts can be higher over iron-based catalysts; over iron-based catalysts the olefin content seems to be limited to ca. 75–80mol-%, whereas the primary olefin content over the cobalt-based catalysts cannot yet be deduced but seems to be higher than 70mol-% in the C3-fraction. It can be further noted that a lower olefin content is obtained over the ruthenium promoted alumina compared to the olefin content over the alumina-containing iron-based catalyst at a given CO-conversion. Furthermore, the limiting value of the olefin content at low conversion for the ruthenium promoted catalyst seems to be lower than that of the unpromoted catalyst. This might originate from a secondary olefin hydrogenation activity of ruthenium rather than of iron. Similarly, the olefin content obtained over the Ruhrchemie-based catalyst drops sharply at high levels of CO-conversion (much more than the alumina containing iron-based catalyst), which might be attributed to a role of the copper surface in the secondary olefin hydrogenation [41]. Fig. 10 shows some characteristics on the selectivity within the C5-fraction, viz. the 1-olefin content in the fraction of linear C5-olefins and the ratio of iso-C iso-isoC5 to n-C5 hydrocarbons. The extent of double bond isomerisation may affect the 1-olefin content and thus the rate of olefin re-incorporation [69]. The 1-olefin content decreases with increasing level of CO-conversion as previously reported [32]. The decrease is stronger over the cobalt-based catalyst than over iron-based catalysts, which may be attributed to the higher reactivity of cobalt-based catalysts for re-adsorption of olefins. It is interesting to note that the 1-olefin content obtained over iron-based catalysts becomes almost independent of carbon number at relatively high level of CO-conversion (40–70%). In this region the 1-olefin content is high (90–95%), but not 100%, which was to be expected if internal olefins are solely secondary products. The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis does not only produce linear hydrocarbons. Branched hydrocarbons will have a different reactivity towards cracking than linear hydrocarbons [70], and hence the ratio of branched to linear products will need to be taken into account, when modelling the overall process. The ratio of iso-C5/n-C5 obtained over the cobalt based catalyst is between 0.05 and 0.08 for CO-conversion up to 65%. A strong increase in the ratio of iso-C5/n-C5 to ca. 0.14 is observed upon increasing the CO-conversion to 91%. This might be attributed to the secondary formation of branched product compounds in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [64,69]. The ratio of iso-C5/n-C5 as a function of CO-conversion obtained over the Ruhrchemie-based catalyst shows almost the opposite trend, which can be expected for primary formation of branched product compounds [64]. The ratio of iso-C5/n-C5 obtained over the alumina containing iron-based catalysts is much higher, 0.23-0.40. It might be tempting to ascribe this to the acid function associated with alumina in the catalyst. However double bond isomerisation which is also catalysed by acids does not seem to be affected. Hence, the formation of branched product compounds must be ascribed to the catalytically active phase for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. 4 Concluding remarks Catalyst suitable for a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis operating at high levels of CO-conversion (as desired for a once-through XTL-process) may differ significantly from the current set of patented and researched catalysts. It is shown that not all cobalt catalysts are necessarily more active than iron-based catalyst at their typically applied reaction conditions. Cobalt-based catalysts have an advantage over iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts, since the CO2 formation over cobalt-based catalysts is limited even going to high conversion resulting in a significantly higher maximum yield of hydrocarbons. Cobalt-based catalysts do produce more methane than the best iron-based catalysts (at least for CO-conversion less than 80%). This is however off-set by a lower selectivity towards C2-C4 hydrocarbons resulting in a C5+-selectivity which is as high as the Ruhrchemie-based catalyst. The selectivity for the desired C5+-fraction starts dropping off for conversion levels larger than 80% for both the Co/TiO2 catalyst and the iron-based Ruhrchemie type catalyst. This is accompanied by a decrease in the average chain growth probability in the C8-C11 range. coredata.dc:description: The XTL-process is a capital-intensive process. Novel process configurations need to be explored to increase the economic viability of this process. This is typically performed using the known dependencies of the catalyst as a function of the targeted process conditions. However, new process conditions may require catalysts with different characteristics compared to those currently utilised. Here, a set of cobalt- and iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts are evaluated for their suitability in the application of a single-pass XTL-process operating at high conversion of synthesis gas. It is shown that cobalt-based catalysts of a suitable activity may be preferred over iron-based catalysts. The higher selectivity for methane for cobalt-based catalysts is offset by a lower selectivity for C2-C4 resulting in a favourable C5+-selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Comparing a cobalt-based catalyst with iron-based catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch XTL-process operating at high conversion
